name: Twitter Archive Analysis
tagline: Using python to analyze and visualize your twitter archive.
body:
### Visualizing my Twitter Archive

So: I've been really interested in data mining and natural language analysis lately. I've set up [tweet mining on linode using MongoDB](https://github.com/laurenarcher/TweetMines) and that's gathering data as we speak, but in the meantime I wanted to get started with something a bit simpler.

I figure the best place to start analyzing Twitter data is with my own Twitter Archive. More information on finding and downloading your Twitter Archive can be found [here](http://blog.twitter.com/2012/12/your-twitter-archive.html).

After a short search around github I found [Dangoldin's](https://github.com/dangoldin/twitter-archive-analysis) **twitter-archive-analysis**, which already did a lot of the things I was interested in, and also seemed like good introduction to some of the python data analysis tools I've been reading about lately, including [numpy](http://www.numpy.org/), [matplotlib](http://matplotlib.org/), and [nltk](http://nltk.org/).

I've made a few adjustments to his code. This is the first time I've ever forked a repo on github, so I'm open to feedback. I think I've made it easier for people of all OS's and experience levels to use. I've also added word cloud visualization with [PyTagCloud](https://github.com/atizo/PyTagCloud).

Now onto the results!

### MatPlotLib

![Tweets by Month](http://dl.dropbox.com/u/50961844/by-month.png)

Here are all of the tweets I've ever made distributed over time by month. It looks like I used to tweet a lot more in 2009-2010, which I will now call 'peak tweet'.

![Day of Week](http://dl.dropbox.com/u/50961844/by-dow.png)

I wouldn't have guessed that I tend the tweet the most on hump day, but it looks like I do more tweeting on Wednesday than I do on any other day of the week.

[This ](http://www.sysomos.com/insidetwitter/)Twitter-wide analysis shows Tuesday, followed by Wednesday as the most popular days to tweet. (Although I've seen variations on this chart that shows Thursday and Friday as the most popular.)

![By Hour](http://dl.dropbox.com/u/50961844/by-hour.png)

I also tend to tweet in the late morning and afternoon, fairly [typical](http://www.sysomos.com/insidetwitter/).

![By Type of Tweet](http://dl.dropbox.com/u/50961844/by-month-type-stacked.png)

This chart stacks the type of tweet by month. At first glance, it looks like I am a lot less original and a lot more social now than I was in 2009. While that may be true, Twitter didn't [formalize RTs](https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=web&cd=1&cad=rja&ved=0CDQQFjAA&url=http%3A%2F%2Fblog.twitter.com%2F2009%2F08%2Fproject-retweet-phase-one.html&ei=cp9lUezHEs-GyQHJ7oGoBg&usg=AFQjCNEH16dZzo_CayjJ3SP-wSOBamKFCg&sig2=B3gWXTr-RostEU4o3nnoIA&bvm=bv.44990110,d.aWc) until the end of 2009, which probably accounts for the bloated original tweet count before then.

![Day of Week, Month, Year](http://dl.dropbox.com/u/50961844/by-month-dow.png)

Here we see 'peak tweet' again, sometime between September 2009 and February 2010. I remember Twitter being a major creative outlet for me at the time. I've since found more creative outlets than I know what to do with. 

### PyTagCloud

Now onto everyone's favourite type of text visualization: Word clouds!

![Most Common Tweet Words](http://dl.dropbox.com/u/50961844/c_most_common.png)

Here are the words I use most often when I tweet. I talk about heritage, Toronto and outer space.

I also _like_ a lot of things.
 
PyTagCloud uses a fairly basic list of stopwords that it omits from word counts. I added internet-specific stopwords like **www** and **http** to the PyTagCloud _english_ stopwords list and so can you!

![Most Common @replies](http://dl.dropbox.com/u/50961844/at_c_most_common.png)

Here are the people I talk at the most.

I played around with the built-in PyTagCloud colour scheme and font options a lot. 

![Most Common #hashtags](http://dl.dropbox.com/u/50961844/hash_c_most_common.png)


And here are the hashtags I've used the most. I mostly see hashtags as gimmicky or event-related. **#builtheritage** is the hashtag used for a monthly twitter chat on the subject, so I use it regularly.

### Feedback is always appreciated.

I am a rookie and forever learning. If I've gotten something completely wrong I'd love it if you could send some constructive criticism my way.
